At build time, it embeds all your posts into vectors and puts them into a vector database. Then, for each paragraph in a post, it queries the vector database for the 20 most similar paragraphs from all your notes. It stores these in a precomputed index. It then statically generates a blog for you (like Gatsby or any other static site generator), and uses this index so users can see related ideas when they click on a paragraph.

[â€˜a writing app built around semantic.content: [follow-up: â€˜a writing app built around semantic searchâ€™](https://iwebthings.joejenett.com/follow-up-a-writing-app-built-around-semantic-search/)

At build time, it embeds all your posts into vectors and puts them into a vector database. Then, for each paragraph in a post, it queries the vector database for the 20 most similar paragraphs from all your notes. It stores these in a precomputed index. It then statically generates a blog for you (like Gatsby or any other static site generator), and uses this index so users can see related ideas when they click on a paragraph.
You're viewing this on a statically generated blog using [Yurt](https://github.com/nichwch/yurt).

There are pros and cons to this approach. The biggest pro is that it generates a static blog. There's no backend to maintain, and it's quite lightweight and loads fast, while also providing the benefit of semantic hyperlinks. The con is that since the index is precomputed, you can't search for arbitrary things like you can in nomad hypertext.
<- [Towards a quieter, friendlier web â€¢ Cory Dransfeldt](https://coryd.dev/posts/2024/towards-a-quieter-friendlier-web/)

The web has changed but there remain remnants of what it once was in terms of personal sites. I track some of those remnants, curating such sites (which are still active, or when Iâ€™m lucky, new), hoping to somehow keep my original vision of the web intact. Itâ€™s a tough road to drive on but Iâ€™ve got a decent set of wheels with a few bells and whistles and more important, I enjoy the driving.

The web has changed but there remain remnants of what it once was in terms of personal sites. I track some of those remnants, curating such sites (which are still active, or when Iâ€™m lucky, new), hoping to somehow keep my original vision of the web intact. Packing us all into the old Ford and hitting the road was the plan of the day.  Running was always the way of dealing with things and this was a run for the gold.
<- [Towards a quieter, friendlier web â€¢ Cory Dransfeldt](https://coryd.dev/posts/2024/towards-a-quieter-friendlier-web/)
[follow-up: â€˜a writing app built around semantic searchâ€™](https://iwebthings.joejenett.com/follow-up-a-writing-app-built-around-semantic-search/)

The long road flies by us as rain hits the hood of the old Ford.  What could we do but go along with this plan?  One day we'll grow up and do our own running.  One day we'll grow up and regress just like she has.
